Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Development of a Smart Pacifier to help parents and pediatricians track early signs of Autism Spectrum Disorder
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the improved identification of young children who may be at risk for Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). Autism is a growing concern as rates continue to increase, however many experts in child development are hopeful that early intervention can help reduce many of the challenges of living with autism. As the brain undergoes important critical periods of development in the first year of life, it is important to try and identify opportunities for intervention as early as infancy. However, infants have limited means to express themselves and it can be difficult for parents and even pediatricians to track the subtle behavioral cues that can be indicative of autism at this early age. The goal of this proposal is to improve access to tools that help make infants developing thinking and social skills more observable to pediatricians and parents. By creating a consumer version of an old technique used by psychologists to understand infant development, this work will increase access to tools to track infants' behaviors related to autism.

The proposed project is novel in its repurposing of an established laboratory psychology tool, the nonnutritive sucking paradigm. Basically, psychologists long ago learned that infants will alter their rate of sucking on a pacifier when they are interested in something. Psychologists recorded from a pacifier to gauge what an infant was interested in as well as an infant's growing understanding of language, social interaction, math, and a wide variety of cognitive and social skills. They also allowed infants to control the presentation of sounds or images through their sucking patterns. This SBIR project is creating a more accessible version of this established smart pacifier technique to allow parents and pediatricians to also better track an infant?s interest, preferences, and social and cognitive development. This effort will develop a consumer friendly smart pacifier that can control sounds or images on software or mobile applications. By designing software that replicates the social and cognitive assessment paradigms in psychology laboratories, the smart pacifier system can increase access to objective behavioral assessment tools. Similar to growing evidence in eye-tracking behavior, this behavioral assessment tool can be used to better assess behaviors that have been linked to the future development of autism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Phase I SBIR demonstrated that an established research tool used for understanding infant neurodevelopment can be successfully used in the home instead of being limited to an academic laboratory environment.  Making this device more accessible will help create a better understanding of infant neurodevelopment in diverse populations and could also enable more objective behavioral assessments of developmental disorders such as autism. Specifically, this award resulted in a prototype of a Smart Pacifier that can measure sucking behavior in infants, and in a Smart Pacifier-controlled mobile app that can record sucking behavior while an infant is presented with various sounds and images.  As sucking is one of the few behaviors an infant can control from birth, and infants naturally change their sucking rate when interested in something, researchers have developed a technique to wire up a pacifier to objectively measure an infant's attention and preference for various images or sounds related to neurodevelopment.  Unfortunately, this platform was first developed in the 1970s and relied on clunky hardware and software that was only available in a few academic laboratories.  To increase access to this established pacifier research tool, we developed a low-cost Smart Pacifier design that is feasible for high-volume manufacturing and can meet consumer safety standards. We successfully connected the Smart Pacifier to an iOS mobile application that can reliably receive and present data on the sucking activity from the Smart Pacifier while also displaying pacifier-controlled images and sounds.  Finally, we successfully demonstrated that infants would accept the Smart Pacifier and would change their sucking behavior when the Smart Pacifier allowed them to control images or sounds, therefore successfully replicating the type of studies previously done only in academic laboratories. This project was disseminated to stakeholders in the early childhood community during presentations to the OpenIdeo Early Childhood Innovation Platform, and through Promise Studio's Early Futures conference.

The first year of an infant's life is a critical window for neurodevelopment and therefore can be the best time for intervention for a potential developmental disorder. However, much of our understanding of what is typical for neurodevelopment is based on studies that rely on a small group of infants who can make time to visit an academic laboratory. By increasing access to this and other objective behavioral assessment tools for infants, we can better track neurodevelopment across populations with diverse backgrounds, environments, socioeconomic status, and health conditions. Helping caregivers better track and observe an infant's neurodevelopment will ultimately help identify the early warning signs of disorders such as autism, hearing & vision impairments, and speech-language delays.
